text:
The score leader has an impact on the stock value of the stock. So, if you want to find the 100-day and 200-day moving averages of the stock, let me help you. I'll look at them over the past few months and I'm going to look at them in the next couple of weeks as well. I'm looking at them in the mean time. I'm not recommending you do anything drastic, but I'm hoping that the stock will eventually rise or fall much lower.
Harvey Nelson is the author of the classic Three Stock Rises podcast. You can listen to it on the Apple Podcasts, Spotify, and Amazon Music app.

text:
.S. Sen. Ben Sasse, R-Iowa, said during a rally Saturday in Des Moines, Iowa.
“Whatever Republicans do for 2020, Sasse said, ‘Don’t let the system be in the shop long enough. The country will be in the shop for a long time.’”
-- “BETHLEHEM ON ‘SOLDOUT’: The Republican Party’s spending priorities for 2020 are much as the party spent during the 2016 election and the midterm elections, and there’s nothing they don’t mention during the campaign, Republican Sen. Mitt Romney says. And, he adds, “America is in the shop for a long time.”

Nebraska Republican Senator Ben Sasse advised his party against prolonging their focus on internal matters, warning that the nation could suffer lasting consequences.

Republican Senator Mitt Romney criticized the party's spending practices, noting similarities to previous election cycles. He added that the country faces ongoing challenges and needs attention.

In Iowa, Republican senator Ben Sasse cautioned his party to avoid prolonged electoral gridlock, warning that it could have lasting consequences for the nation.

Similarly, fellow Republican senator Mitt Romney has criticized the party's spending patterns, equating the current situation to a "prolonged maintenance period" that could hinder America's recovery.

Republican Senator Ben Sasse warns against prolonging the Republican party's overhaul. He advises against extending the "system overhaul" process, fearing it would have lasting negative consequences for the nation.

Meanwhile, Senator Mitt Romney criticizes the Republican Party's spending practices, noting their similarities to those in previous elections. He believes these tactics will lead to long-term challenges for America.

In a recent rally in Des Moines, Iowa, Republican Senator Ben Sasse advised his party to prioritize their 2020 spending cautiously. He emphasized that prolonged political turmoil could have lasting consequences for the nation.

Meanwhile, Senator Mitt Romney notes that the Republican Party's campaign priorities for 2020 remain largely consistent with their strategies in the 2016 presidential election and the midterm elections. He also echoes Sasse's concern, stating that the country faces an extended period of political and social challenges.

This sentiment aligns with the observations of Senator Mitt Romney, who noted the similarities between the Republican Party's spending strategies for the 2020 election and those employed in previous elections.
